parts:
FROM node:20-alpine
RUN apk add --no-cache python3 g++ make
WORKDIR /app
COPY . .
RUN yarn install --production
CMD ["node", "/app/src/index.js"]

It looks like you've provided a Dockerfile snippet that sets up a container using the Node.js 20 image based on the Alpine Linux distribution. Here's a breakdown of what each line is doing:

1. **`FROM node:20-alpine`**: This line specifies that the base image for the Docker container will be Node.js version 20, based on the lightweight Alpine Linux distribution.
2. **`RUN apk add --no-cache python3 g++ make`**: This command installs Python 3, the GNU C++ compiler, and GNU Make using the Alpine package manager (apk). The `--no-cache` option means that the package manager cache will not be retained, reducing the image size.
3. **`WORKDIR /app`**: This sets the working directory inside the container to `/app`. Any subsequent instructions in the Dockerfile will be executed in this directory.
4. **`COPY . .`**: This copies all the files from the current directory on the host machine into the current directory (i.e., `/app`) inside the container.
5. **`RUN yarn install --production`**: This runs the Yarn package manager to install the dependencies listed in the `package.json` file. The `--production` flag ensures that only production dependencies are installed, excluding any development dependencies.
6. **`CMD ["node", "/app/src/index.js"]`**: This specifies the command to be run when the container starts. In this case, it will execute the `index.js` file inside the `/app/src` directory using Node.js.

This Dockerfile is suitable for building a container that runs a Node.js application, with dependencies on Python, G++, and Make. Make sure that the required files, such as `package.json` and the application source code, are present in the directory where you run the Docker build command.

parts:
"A container is a process on your computer. It's isolated from all other processes on the host computer. That isolation uses kernel namespaces and control groups."

Please explain in simpler terms

Certainly! Let's break down the concept of a container into simpler terms.

Imagine your computer is a big apartment building, and each program running on your computer is like a person living in an apartment. Normally, these people can interact with each other, borrow things, and even cause problems for one another.

A container is like giving one of these people (a program) their own special apartment (a space on your computer) with its own locked doors and walls. They have everything they need inside their apartment, and they can't easily interact with or disturb the other people (programs) in the building.

The "kernel namespaces" are like the locked doors and walls that keep the person inside their own space. They make sure that the person can't see or touch anything outside their apartment.

The "control groups" are like rules that say how much of the building's resources (like water and electricity) the person in the special apartment can use. This ensures that they don't use up everything and leave nothing for the others.

So, a container is a way to run a program on your computer in its own special space, where it can't interfere with other programs, and where it has limits on how much of the computer's resources it can use. It's like a more controlled and isolated way to run a program.

here is a quote from documentation: "The command you just ran¶
Congratulations! You have started the container for this tutorial! Let's first explain the command that you just ran. In case you forgot, here's the command:


docker run -d -p 80:80 docker/getting-started
You'll notice a few flags being used. Here's some more info on them:

-d - run the container in detached mode (in the background)
-p 80:80 - map port 80 of the host to port 80 in the container
docker/getting-started - the image to use"

Can you talk about what is happening when we "map port 80 of the host to port 80 in the container" ?

Certainly! When you "map port 80 of the host to port 80 in the container," you're creating a connection between your computer (the host) and the isolated environment of the container. Let's break down what this means:

1. **Port 80 on the Host**: This refers to a communication endpoint on your computer. Think of it like a door in your house that leads outside. Port 80 is commonly used for web traffic, so it's like the main entrance for web visitors.

2. **Port 80 in the Container**: Inside the container (the isolated apartment we talked about earlier), there's also a door labeled 80. This door inside the container is set up to receive web visitors, just like the main entrance to your house.

3. **Mapping Port 80 to Port 80**: By mapping port 80 of the host to port 80 in the container, you're connecting these two doors. It's like setting up a hallway that directly connects the main entrance of your house to the door inside the special apartment.

When a web visitor comes to your computer's main entrance (port 80 on the host), they are directly guided through the hallway to the door inside the container (port 80 in the container). This allows the visitor to interact with the program running inside the container as if it were running directly on your computer.

This mapping is essential for containers because it allows the isolated environment to communicate with the outside world. Without this connection, the program inside the container would be like a person locked in an apartment with no way to interact with anyone outside. By mapping the ports, you create a controlled pathway for information to flow in and out of the container.
communication endpoint?

A communication endpoint refers to a specific point where interactions occur in a network. It's like an address or a meeting place where two parties can exchange information.

In the context of computer networking, an endpoint can be an IP address, a URL, or a specific port on a device. When we talk about "port 80" as a communication endpoint, we're referring to a specific "door" or "gate" on a computer that's designated for receiving certain types of network traffic, typically web traffic.

Here's a simple analogy:

- **IP Address**: Think of this as the street address of a building. It tells you where the building is located in the city (or on the internet).
- **Port**: This is like a specific door or entrance in that building. There might be many doors for different purposes (e.g., main entrance, service entrance, garage). Each door has a number, and different numbers are used for different types of interactions. Port 80, for example, is like the main entrance for web visitors.

So, a communication endpoint is a specific location where data can be sent or received. It's a crucial concept in networking, as it allows different devices and programs to know exactly where to send or look for information.
is an endpoint one way it terms of traffic

An endpoint in networking is not one-way; it can facilitate both incoming and outgoing traffic. It serves as a point where data can be sent or received, allowing for two-way communication.

Here's how it works:

- **Incoming Traffic**: When someone wants to access a service on your computer (like a web server), they send a request to the appropriate endpoint (e.g., port 80). Your computer receives this request at the specified endpoint and can then respond accordingly.

- **Outgoing Traffic**: Similarly, if your computer wants to access a service on another device, it sends a request to the appropriate endpoint on that device. The other device receives the request and can respond.

So, an endpoint is like a door that can be used for both entering and exiting. It's a meeting point where two parties can exchange information, whether sending or receiving, allowing for two-way communication.
Can you explain a container vs container image?

Certainly! The terms "container" and "container image" are related but refer to different concepts in the world of containerization. Let's break down the differences:

### Container Image

- **What It Is**: A container image is like a blueprint or a recipe. It's a static file that contains all the instructions, code, libraries, and dependencies needed to create a container.
- **Role**: The image defines what the container's environment should look like and what application(s) it should run. It's a snapshot of everything needed to create a consistent and isolated environment.
- **Reusability**: You can use the same container image to create multiple containers, ensuring that each one has the exact same setup. It's like using the same recipe to bake multiple cakes; each cake will have the same ingredients and taste.

### Container

- **What It Is**: A container is a running instance created from a container image. It's like a cake that's been baked using the recipe (the image).
- **Role**: The container is where the application actually runs. It's an isolated environment on your computer that operates based on the instructions and components defined in the image.
- **Uniqueness**: While you can create multiple containers from the same image, each container is a separate and isolated entity. It can have its own state, data, and interactions with other parts of the system.

### Analogy

Think of the container image as a recipe for a cake, and the container as the actual cake itself:

- **Container Image (Recipe)**: Lists all the ingredients and steps needed to bake the cake. You can share this recipe with others, and they can bake the same cake using it.
- **Container (Cake)**: The physical cake that's been baked using the recipe. You can eat it, share it, or even modify it by adding frosting or decorations. But if you want to bake another cake, you'll refer back to the original recipe (image).

In summary, the container image is the static definition that describes what a container should be, while the container is the live, running environment created from that image.
and dockerfiles?

Dockerfiles play a crucial role in the creation of container images, adding another layer to the containerization process. Here's how they fit into the picture:

### Dockerfile

- **What It Is**: A Dockerfile is a text file that contains a set of instructions used to create a container image. It's like writing down the recipe for a cake, step by step.
- **Instructions**: The Dockerfile includes commands to set up the operating system, install applications, copy files, set environment variables, and more. Each line in the Dockerfile adds a new layer to the image, building it up incrementally.
- **Building an Image**: By running a command like `docker build`, you can use the Dockerfile to create a container image. Docker reads the instructions in the Dockerfile and executes them in order, creating a new image layer for each step.
- **Reproducibility**: Since the Dockerfile explicitly defines how the image should be built, anyone with the Dockerfile can create the exact same image. This ensures consistency across different environments.

### Relationship to Containers and Images

- **Dockerfile → Image**: You use the Dockerfile to build a container image. It's the blueprint for the image, detailing every step needed to create it.
- **Image → Container**: Once you have the container image (built from the Dockerfile), you can use it to create running containers. The image is the static snapshot, and the container is the live, running instance.

### Summary

The Dockerfile is the starting point in the containerization process. It's where you write down all the instructions needed to build a container image. Once you have the image, you can use it to create running containers. In the cake analogy, the Dockerfile is like writing down the recipe, the image is the recipe itself, and the container is the actual cake.

parts: do FNH of liver cause pain

Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a benign condition of the liver that often doesn't present with any symptoms. Most people with FNH of the liver do not experience pain or any other symptoms. However, in some cases, particularly if the FNH is large or if there are other underlying conditions, there might be some discomfort or non-specific symptoms.

If you or someone you know is experiencing any discomfort or pain, it would be best to consult with a healthcare provider who can examine the situation and make a proper diagnosis and treatment plan tailored to the specific condition and individual needs.

Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a benign liver lesion that is generally considered asymptomatic. In most cases, it doesn't cause any pain or discomfort.

However, some patients might report nonspecific symptoms such as discomfort in the right upper abdomen. These symptoms are typically not directly related to FNH but could be associated with other underlying conditions or even the anxiety and stress of knowing about the lesion.

If FNH lesions are large, there could potentially be some discomfort or pressure, although this is uncommon. In general, FNH itself is not linked to significant pain or symptoms.
I have a likely FNH only 1.5 cm, but it is very painful. Does this sound strange

While focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is generally considered to be asymptomatic or not causing pain, every individual's experience can be different. That said, it is relatively uncommon for a small FNH lesion of 1.5 cm to cause significant pain. Typically, pain associated with liver lesions might be expected with larger lesions or those that have complications, such as bleeding. However, individual experiences can vary.

If you're experiencing pain, it's important to consider other possible causes. Abdominal pain can be the result of various conditions that may not be related to the liver or the FNH lesion itself. For instance, gallbladder issues, gastrointestinal conditions, or musculoskeletal problems could potentially cause similar symptoms.

If you're experiencing persistent or worsening symptoms, it's crucial to consult with healthcare professionals for a thorough evaluation. Diagnostic tests may include further imaging studies, blood tests, or even a biopsy, depending on your medical history and other symptoms.

- **Introduction**:

- **Concept of Polymorphic Applications**:
  - Polymorphic applications are self-changing software.
  - David refers to a recent keynote by Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella, emphasizing the importance of AI and its capabilities, particularly in natural language interfaces and reasoning engines. [Link to video segment](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y1gBosXlM8c&t=62s)

- **Mission-Oriented Programming**:
  - David introduces the concept of mission-oriented programming as the next paradigm beyond object-oriented programming.
  - In this paradigm, software is designed around a clear, measurable, and purposeful mission.
  - Polymorphic applications are seen as active agents in pursuing their missions. [Link to video segment](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y1gBosXlM8c&t=208s)

- **Generative AI as Automation**:
  - Generative AI models, like GPT, are viewed as a type of automation.
  - These models can write code, solve problems, make decisions, and more.
  - David emphasizes the importance of modularity and the ability to "print" or fabricate code on demand. [Link to video segment](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y1gBosXlM8c&t=263s)

- **Cognitive Architecture**:
  - David delves into the concept of cognitive architecture, which he describes as the framework for creating advanced AI entities.
  - He introduces the ACE model (Autonomous Cognitive Entities) which consists of six layers: Aspirational, Global Strategy, Agent Model, Executive Function, Cognitive Control, and Task Prosecution. [Link to video segment](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y1gBosXlM8c&t=580s)
  - Each layer has its specific function, from setting the mission and values at the topmost layer to executing tasks at the bottommost layer.

please generate 5 questions. They are for middle school students in a computer science class. The goal is to get them to find interesting and nuanced topics related to computer science that they can learn more about. The problem is that they don't know what they don't know, so when I ask them "what are you interested in technology" they don't even know how to answer. I want the questions to promote or encourage them to have to search around to find answers. These students are 12-13. Please help. Topics should be related to curent things like AI or others

Certainly! Here are five questions tailored to pique the interest of middle school students in the realm of computer science, with a particular emphasis on contemporary subjects like AI:

1. **Virtual Assistants and AI**: "Smart speakers, like Amazon's Alexa or Google Home, can answer your questions, play music, and even control your lights. How do these virtual assistants work? What is the role of Artificial Intelligence in making them respond to our commands?"
   
   *Purpose*: To encourage students to delve into the inner workings of smart speakers and understand the blend of AI, natural language processing, and cloud computing.
   
2. **Video Games and Graphics**: "When you play a video game, characters move smoothly, landscapes are detailed, and the physics feels real. What computer science concepts help create these realistic video game environments? Are there specific algorithms or technologies that make it possible?"
   
   *Purpose*: Allows students to relate computer science to their hobbies and learn about graphics rendering, physics simulations, and the use of algorithms in game development.
   
3. **Deepfakes and Media**: "You may have seen videos where a famous person appears to say or do something they never did. These are often called 'deepfakes'. How are these videos created and why is it important for us to understand and detect them?"
   
   *Purpose*: Introduces students to the topic of deep learning, the ethics around AI-manipulated media, and the importance of discerning truth in the digital age.
   
4. **Robotic Automation**: "Robots are now used in many industries to perform tasks - from making cars to delivering packages. What are some of the latest advancements in robotics, and how do computer scientists help robots to 'see' and 'think'?"
   
   *Purpose*: Encourages students to research robotics, machine vision, and the AI that powers these machines, prompting them to think about the future of automation.
   
5. **Social Media Algorithms**: "When you use social media platforms like TikTok, Instagram, or YouTube, you often see recommended videos or posts. How do these platforms decide what content to show you, and what role does AI play in these decisions?"
   
   *Purpose*: Gets students to think critically about the technology they use daily and introduces them to the world of recommendation algorithms and machine learning.

Remember, it can also be helpful to provide students with some initial resources or platforms to start their research, ensuring that they're accessing reliable and age-appropriate information.
Please generate a list of topics and subtopics related to computer science that might interest middle school students who know nothing about technology but intereact with it often

Absolutely! Here's a list of computer science topics and subtopics tailored for middle school students:

### 1. **Video Games**
   - **Game Design**: How are games conceptualized and created?
   - **Graphics**: How are 3D characters and environments made?
   - **Physics in Games**: How do game objects move and interact realistically?
   - **Multiplayer Networks**: How can players from around the world play together?

### 2. **Social Media**
   - **Algorithms**: How does TikTok or Instagram know what video or picture to show you next?
   - **Safety**: How do platforms protect users and their data?
   - **Virtual Reality (VR)**: How is VR used in social media?

### 3. **Smart Devices**
   - **Smartphones**: How do apps work? What makes touch screens touch-sensitive?
   - **Smart Home Devices**: How can you control lights or play music with just your voice?
   - **Wearables**: How do smartwatches and fitness trackers monitor your activities?

### 4. **Artificial Intelligence**
   - **Virtual Assistants**: How does Siri, Alexa, or Google Assistant understand what you say?
   - **Deepfakes**: How can AI create realistic-looking but fake content?
   - **Self-driving Cars**: How can cars drive themselves safely?

### 5. **Internet and Web**
   - **Websites**: How are websites made and hosted?
   - **Online Safety**: How can you stay safe while browsing the internet?
   - **Search Engines**: How do Google, Bing, and others find what you're looking for?

### 6. **Robotics**
   - **Robotic Automation**: How are robots used in factories or hospitals?
   - **Drone Technology**: How do drones fly and capture images?
   - **Robotic Pets**: How do robotic dogs or cats mimic real animals?

### 7. **Multimedia**
   - **Animation**: How are animated movies or cartoons created?
   - **Virtual Reality**: How can you feel like you're in a different place using VR headsets?
   - **Digital Music**: How is music created and edited on computers?

### 8. **Coding and Programming**
   - **Programming Languages**: How do computers understand code?
   - **Mobile App Development**: How are apps made for phones and tablets?
   - **Scratch and Blockly**: How can you make a game or animation without writing code?

### 9. **Cybersecurity**
   - **Hacking**: How do hackers breach systems, and how can we protect against them?
   - **Viruses and Malware**: How do they work, and how can they affect your devices?
   - **Digital Footprint**: What information are you sharing online?

### 10. **Hardware and Electronics**
   - **Computer Components**: What's inside a computer or tablet?
   - **Gadgets**: How do new tech gadgets get designed and made?
   - **3D Printing**: How can you print objects in 3D?

The key is to relate these topics to their daily experiences and show the magic behind the technology they interact with. Encouraging hands-on projects or activities related to these topics will further enhance their interest and understanding.
please continue the list

### 11. **Digital Art and Design**
   - **Digital Illustration**: How are digital drawings and graphics created?
   - **3D Modeling**: How are characters and objects designed for video games and movies?
   - **Graphic Design**: How are posters, websites, and apps made visually appealing?

### 12. **Augmented Reality (AR)**

About forwarded ports

Alright, let's break this down into a simpler explanation.

---

**What is Github Codespaces?**

Think of GitHub Codespaces as your computer's coding environment, but instead of it being on your personal computer, it's on the internet, and you can access it through your web browser. It's like having a version of the Visual Studio Code (a popular coding program) that you can use from anywhere, on any device, as long as you have an internet connection.

---

**What does "forward ports" mean?**

When you run certain programs or apps, they communicate using specific "doors" called ports. Sometimes, you want to access these programs from a different location (like from your local computer). "Forwarding" a port is like redirecting traffic from one of these doors so you can reach that program from another place.

---

**Why would I want to forward ports in my codespace?**

Imagine you're building a website. Within your codespace, the website might be running on a specific door (port). If you want to view how this website looks in a browser on your own computer, you'd need to forward the port. This lets you see and test your website as if it's live, but it's only running in your codespace.

---

**How does GitHub Codespaces make this easy?**

When you're using the codespace and a program mentions a link like `http://localhost:PORT`, GitHub Codespaces understands you might want to see that in your browser. So, it automatically sets up the port forwarding and even gives you a clickable link. This way, with just a click, you can view what's running on that port.

---

**What else should I know about forwarding ports in Codespaces?**

1. **Automatic vs Manual**: While some ports are forwarded automatically, you can also set it up manually if needed.
2. **Labels**: You can give names to forwarded ports to remember what each one is for.
3. **Sharing**: You can share these forwarded ports. This means if you want a team member to see your website or app, you can give them access.
4. **Configuring**: For frequent projects, you can set rules so that certain ports are always forwarded when you open that project in Codespaces.

---

Please talk about the port forwarding aspect in greater detail and within the context of codespaces. Break it down using analogies

Alright, let's dive deeper into the concept of port forwarding within the context of Codespaces, using some analogies to make it clearer.

---

**What's a Port?**  
*Analogy*: Imagine you live in a large apartment building (your computer or Codespace). Each apartment in the building has a specific door number (port number). Just like how you'd tell a friend to visit you at a certain apartment number, applications specify a port number when they want to communicate or provide a service.

---

**What is Port Forwarding?**  
*Analogy*: Suppose you are staying temporarily in a hotel (this is your Codespace), but your mail (data or service) is still being delivered to your permanent apartment. Port forwarding is like telling the mail carrier, "Hey, while I'm at this hotel, please redirect or forward my mail from my apartment's door to my hotel room's door." This allows you to access or see the mail (or the application's service) from your hotel, even though it's technically meant for your apartment.

---

**Why Forward Ports in Codespaces?**  
Within the context of Codespaces, your codespace (the hotel in our analogy) is a remote, separate environment. If you're running a web application in that environment, it's as if the website is hosted from your hotel room. By forwarding the port, you're making sure you can still access it from your main apartment or even let friends (other devices or colleagues) visit it.

---

**How Does Automatic Port Forwarding Work in Codespaces?**  
*Analogy*: When you check into certain tech-savvy hotels, they might automatically forward your mail if they notice it has your name on it. Similarly, when an application running inside your Codespace shows a local link (like `http://localhost:PORT`), GitHub Codespaces recognizes this and thinks, "Oh! This looks important. Let's automatically set up port forwarding for this!" It then gives you a link that acts as a doorbell to that hotel room, allowing you to access what's inside.

---

**Customizing Port Forwarding and Sharing**  
*Analogy*: Sometimes, you might want specific parcels or types of mail forwarded to your hotel, or you might want to allow certain friends to pick up mail from your apartment's door. In the digital realm of Codespaces, this is where customization comes in. You can:

1. **Set Specific Rules**: Like telling the mail carrier to only forward packages or letters. In Codespaces, this means you set up rules in the container configuration to always forward certain ports when you use that codespace.
2. **Labeling Ports**: Like sticking a sticky-note on forwarded mail that says "Birthday Cards" or "Bills." This helps you quickly identify why you forwarded certain mail. Similarly, in Codespaces, you can label forwarded ports to remember their purpose.
3. **Sharing**: Suppose you want a family member to pick up your mail. In Codespaces, this is like sharing the forwarded port with a colleague. They can then access the application or service running on that port, just like they're looking at the mail meant for your door.

---

I hope that these analogies help clarify the concept of port forwarding within Codespaces for you!
can you give an example of a project that might use port forwarding

Certainly! Let's consider a common scenario in the world of software development: **Developing a Web Application**.

---

### **Web Application Development in Codespaces**

**The Project**:  
You're developing a new web application called "PhotoShare" where users can share and comment on photographs. The application consists of:

1. A front-end that users interact with directly (made using React, for instance).
2. A back-end server that manages user data, photo uploads, and comments (maybe using Node.js and Express).

During development, you want to run the application, test features, identify bugs, and see the UI changes in real-time.

---

**Local Development without Codespaces**:  
If you were developing this on your local machine (your personal computer):

1. You would start the back-end server, and it might say: "Server running on http://localhost:5000".
2. You'd start the front-end, and it might say: "React app running on http://localhost:3000".

You could then open a web browser on your computer, navigate to those addresses, and interact with your application.

---

**Development in Codespaces**:  
Now, imagine you're working on this project using GitHub Codespaces instead of your local machine.

1. In your codespace, you start the back-end server, and as before, it says it's running on `http://localhost:5000`.
2. You also start the front-end, and it mentions `http://localhost:3000`.

Here's the catch: the application is running inside Codespaces, which is in a remote environment – not directly on your computer. So, if you just try to access those addresses on your local browser, it won't work.

---

**This is Where Port Forwarding Comes In**:  

Using the port forwarding feature in Codespaces:

1. When your back-end server mentions `http://localhost:5000`, Codespaces can automatically recognize this and set up port forwarding. It does the same for the front-end on port 3000.
2. Codespaces will then provide you with specific URLs, which you can click on. These URLs will look different from the usual `localhost` addresses but will lead you to your running applications.
3. You can now open these URLs in your local web browser and interact with the PhotoShare application just like if it was running directly on your computer.

**Bonus - Collaborative Debugging**:
Suppose you encounter a bug or a design element you're unsure about and want feedback from a colleague. You can share the forwarded port URL with them. They can then access the running application on their computer, even though it's technically running in your Codespaces environment. This makes collaborative debugging and design feedback much easier.

---

This example showcases the convenience and power of port forwarding in a development environment like Codespaces. It bridges the gap between a remote development environment and local, real-time testing and debugging.

Is a malignant tumor more or less likley to cause pain than a benign tumor? Or is there no signifigant difference

The relationship between tumor malignancy and pain is complex and can vary based on the location of the tumor, its size, the rate of growth, and other factors. Here's a general overview:

Location and Invasion: Malignant tumors are more likely to invade surrounding tissues and structures, which can lead to pain. For instance, a malignant bone tumor might cause more pain than a benign one because it can destroy bone tissue more aggressively. Similarly, tumors near or invading nerves, blood vessels, or other sensitive structures can cause pain.

Size and Growth Rate: Rapidly growing tumors, often malignant, can stretch the capsule of an organ or press against neighboring structures, leading to pain. However, large benign tumors can also cause pain if they compress adjacent structures.

Necrosis and Inflammation: Malignant tumors can outgrow their blood supply, leading to areas of necrosis (dead tissue) within the tumor. This necrosis can cause inflammation and pain.

Hormonal or Biochemical Effects: Some tumors, both benign and malignant, can produce substances that cause pain or other symptoms. For example, certain lung tumors can produce hormone-like substances that affect distant organs and tissues, leading to symptoms.

Metastasis: Malignant tumors can metastasize (spread) to distant sites, which can cause pain at those sites. Benign tumors do not metastasize.

Individual Variation: Pain perception varies among individuals. Some people might have a large tumor (benign or malignant) and experience minimal to no pain, while others with a smaller tumor might experience significant pain.

In summary, while malignant tumors are often associated with pain due to their aggressive nature and potential to invade surrounding structures, benign tumors can also cause pain, especially if they are large or located near sensitive structures. Pain alone cannot definitively differentiate between benign and malignant tumors; a comprehensive evaluation, including imaging and sometimes biopsy, is necessary.

Idiopathic Causes: Sometimes, the exact cause of the pain might not be clear, and it's termed idiopathic.

It's also worth noting that the liver has a capsule, and any lesion or inflammation can stretch this capsule, leading to pain in the right upper quadrant. The described lesion in the liver, even if small, might be the cause of the pain due to one or more of the reasons mentioned above.

However, it's essential to consider other potential causes of right upper quadrant pain, such as gallbladder disease, which is a common cause of pain in this region. Is a malignant tumor more or less likley to cause pain than a benign tumor? Or is there no signifigant difference

The relationship between tumor malignancy and pain is complex and can vary based on the location of the tumor, its size, the rate of growth, and other factors. Here's a general overview:

1. **Location and Invasion:** Malignant tumors are more likely to invade surrounding tissues and structures, which can lead to pain. For instance, a malignant bone tumor might cause more pain than a benign one because it can destroy bone tissue more aggressively. Similarly, tumors near or invading nerves, blood vessels, or other sensitive structures can cause pain.

2. **Size and Growth Rate:** Rapidly growing tumors, often malignant, can stretch the capsule of an organ or press against neighboring structures, leading to pain. However, large benign tumors can also cause pain if they compress adjacent structures.

3. **Necrosis and Inflammation:** Malignant tumors can outgrow their blood supply, leading to areas of necrosis (dead tissue) within the tumor. This necrosis can cause inflammation and pain.

4. **Hormonal or Biochemical Effects:** Some tumors, both benign and malignant, can produce substances that cause pain or other symptoms. For example, certain lung tumors can produce hormone-like substances that affect distant organs and tissues, leading to symptoms.

5. **Metastasis:** Malignant tumors can metastasize (spread) to distant sites, which can cause pain at those sites. Benign tumors do not metastasize.

6. **Individual Variation:** Pain perception varies among individuals. Some people might have a large tumor (benign or malignant) and experience minimal to no pain, while others with a smaller tumor might experience significant pain.

In summary, while malignant tumors are often associated with pain due to their aggressive nature and potential to invade surrounding structures, benign tumors can also cause pain, especially if they are large or located near sensitive structures. The imaging findings provided describe a lesion in the liver, specifically in segment II of the left hepatic lobe. The key features of this lesion are:

1. **MRI with Eovist**:
   - T2 hyperintensity
   - T1 hypointensity
   - Arterial enhancement
   - Persistent contrast enhancement on delayed imaging sequences
   - No central scar

2. **3 phase liver CT**:
   - Arterial enhancing lesion in segment 2 of the left hepatic lobe
   - Not seen during portal venous or delayed phases of contrast

Given these findings, the lesion is most consistent with a **Hepatic Hemangioma**. Here's why:

- **Hepatic Hemangioma**: These are benign vascular liver lesions and are the most common benign liver tumors. On MRI, they typically appear as T2 hyperintense and T1 hypointense. The enhancement pattern on MRI after contrast administration is characteristic: they show peripheral nodular enhancement in the arterial phase with progressive centripetal fill-in on delayed images. The CT findings of arterial phase enhancement that is not seen in the portal venous or delayed phases also support this diagnosis.

Other differential diagnoses for liver lesions include:

- **Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC)**: This is a primary liver cancer. It can show arterial phase hyperenhancement and washout in the portal venous or delayed phases. However, the persistent enhancement on delayed MRI sequences makes HCC less likely in this case.
  
- **Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH)**: This is a benign liver lesion. It can show arterial phase enhancement and might have a central scar. However, the absence of a central scar in this lesion makes FNH less likely.

- **Liver Metastases**: These are secondary liver tumors from another primary cancer site. Their imaging appearance can vary widely depending on the primary cancer type. Given the imaging findings, metastases seem less likely.

- **Hepatic Adenoma**: This is a benign liver tumor that can sometimes undergo malignant transformation. It might show arterial phase enhancement, but the imaging findings provided are more consistent with a hemangioma.

Given the imaging findings and the absence of other concerning features, a hepatic hemangioma is the most likely diagnosis. However, clinical correlation and possibly follow-up imaging or biopsy might be needed to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other possibilities.

No additional liver lesion is seen. The gallbladder is normal. No intrahepatic or extrahepatic biliary dilation. The left hepatic lobe lesion demonstrates T2 hyperintensity, T1 hypointensity, arterial enhancement, and persistent contrast enhancement on delayed imaging sequences. No central scar is noted.

I'm not a doctor, but based on the MRI findings you provided, the lesion in the liver demonstrates some characteristic features:

1. **T2 hyperintensity and T1 hypointensity**: This suggests that the lesion is brighter on T2-weighted images compared to the surrounding liver tissue and darker on T1-weighted images compared to the surrounding liver tissue.
 
2. **Arterial enhancement**: The lesion takes up the contrast agent during the arterial phase of imaging.

3. **Persistent contrast enhancement on delayed imaging sequences**: The lesion continues to show enhancement even after some time has passed since the contrast agent was given. This is also known as "washout."

4. **No central scar is noted**: Some liver lesions, like focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH), might have a central scar, which is a hallmark of the lesion. But it's not present in this case.

Based on these characteristics, a few differential diagnoses might include:

1. **Hepatocellular adenoma (HCA)**: These are benign tumors that arise from the hepatocytes (the main liver cell type). Some subtypes of HCA can demonstrate arterial enhancement with persistent enhancement on delayed sequences. The absence of a central scar might favor HCA over FNH.

2. **Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH)**: Another benign liver lesion. Some might not show the typical central scar, and it can have arterial enhancement and persistent enhancement on delayed imaging.

3. **Early hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)**: This is a malignant tumor of the liver. The pattern of arterial phase enhancement followed by washout in the delayed phase is a typical feature of HCC. However, the persistent contrast enhancement on delayed imaging might make this less likely.

4. **Other liver lesions**: The liver can have various other lesions like hemangiomas, metastases, etc. However, the imaging characteristics you've provided might not be typical for these.

Given the imaging findings, it is crucial to correlate with the patient's clinical history, laboratory findings (like liver function tests, alpha-fetoprotein levels, etc.), and risk factors (like hepatitis, cirrhosis, oral contraceptive use, etc.). A biopsy might be needed for definitive diagnosis in some cases.

The patient should discuss these findings with a hepatologist or a radiologist who can provide a more precise diagnosis and guidance on next steps.
The patient also has a low whit blood cell count

A low white blood cell count (leukopenia) can have various causes. The combination of a hepatic lesion with the described imaging characteristics and leukopenia could raise concerns about several potential diagnoses or conditions. Some considerations include:

1. **Malignancy with Bone Marrow Involvement**: Some malignancies can spread to the bone marrow and suppress its function, leading to leukopenia. This would be more concerning if the liver lesion is indeed a metastasis from another primary site.

2. **Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)**: While HCC itself doesn't typically cause leukopenia, advanced liver disease (like cirrhosis) can sometimes be associated with hematological abnormalities. However, there should be other signs or symptoms of liver dysfunction.

3. **Medications**: Some medications can suppress bone marrow function, leading to a decrease in white blood cells. If the patient is on any medications, especially chemotherapy, immunosuppressants, or certain antibiotics, these should be reviewed as potential causes.

4. **Infections**: Chronic or acute infections, particularly viral infections like hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or HIV, can be associated with liver lesions and leukopenia.

5. **Autoimmune Conditions**: Conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can affect both the liver and the bone marrow, leading to liver abnormalities and leukopenia.

6. **Bone Marrow Disorders**: Conditions that affect the bone marrow directly, like myelodysplastic syndromes, can lead to leukopenia. These would typically have other associated blood count abnormalities.

7. **Other Causes**: There are many other potential causes of leukopenia, including nutritional deficiencies (like B12 or folate), radiation exposure, and congenital conditions.

Given the complexity and potential seriousness of the findings, a thorough workup is warranted. This would typically involve a combination of additional blood tests, potentially imaging of other sites, and consultations with specialists (like a hepatologist, hematologist, or oncologist).

  OHIF Medical Imaging Viewer
  The OHIF Viewer is a zero-footprint medical image viewer
provided by the Open Health Imaging Foundation (OHIF). It is a configurable and extensible progressive web application with out-of-the-box support for image archives which support DICOMweb.



























Measurement Tracking
Demo



Labelmap Segmentations
Demo



Fusion and Custom Hanging protocols
Demo



Slide Microscopy
Demo



Volume Rendering
Demo



About
The OHIF Medical Imaging Viewer is for viewing medical images. It can retrieve
and load images from most sources and formats; render sets in 2D, 3D, and
reconstructed representations; allows for the manipulation, annotation, and
serialization of observations; supports internationalization, OpenID Connect,
offline use, hotkeys, and many more features.
Almost everything offers some degree of customization and configuration. If it
doesn't support something you need, we accept pull requests and have an ever
improving Extension System.
Why Choose Us
Community & Experience
The OHIF Viewer is a collaborative effort that has served as the basis for many
active, production, and FDA Cleared medical imaging viewers. It benefits from
our extensive community's collective experience, and from the sponsored
contributions of individuals, research groups, and commercial organizations.
Built to Adapt
After more than 8-years of integrating with many companies and organizations,
The OHIF Viewer has been rebuilt from the ground up to better address the
varying workflow and configuration needs of its many users. All of the Viewer's
core features are built using it's own extension system. The same extensibility
that allows us to offer:

2D and 3D medical image viewing
Multiplanar Reconstruction (MPR)
Maximum Intensity Project (MIP)
Whole slide microscopy viewing
PDF and Dicom Structured Report rendering
Segmentation rendering as labelmaps and contours
User Access Control (UAC)
Context specific toolbar and side panel content
and many others

Can be leveraged by you to customize the viewer for your workflow, and to add
any new functionality you may need (and wish to maintain privately without
forking).
Support

Report a Bug 🐛
Request a Feature 🚀
Ask a Question 🤗
Slack Channel

For commercial support, academic collaborations, and answers to common
questions; please use Get Support to contact
us.
Developing
Branches
master branch - The latest dev (beta) release

master - The latest dev release

This is typically where the latest development happens. Code that is in the master branch has passed code reviews and automated tests, but it may not be deemed ready for production. This branch usually contains the most recent changes and features being worked on by the development team. It's often the starting point for creating feature branches (where new features are developed) and hotfix branches (for urgent fixes).
Each package is tagged with beta version numbers, and published to npm such as @ohif/ui@3.6.0-beta.1
release branch - The latest stable release
This branch represents the latest stable version of the project that is considered ready for production. The code in this branch should be fully tested and vetted for release. Once the code in the master branch reaches a state where it's stable and ready to be released to users,
we do a comprehensive code review and QA testing. Once the code is approved,
we merge it into the release branch and tag a new release.
Each package is tagged with version numbers, and published to npm such as @ohif/ui@3.5.0
Note: master is always ahead of release branch. We publish both docker builds for beta and stable releases.
Here is a schematic representation of our development workflow:

Requirements

Yarn 1.17.3+
Node 16+
Yarn Workspaces should be enabled on your machine:

yarn config set workspaces-experimental true



Getting Started

Fork this repository
Clone your forked repository

git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/Viewers.git


Navigate to the cloned project's directory
Add this repo as a remote named upstream

git remote add upstream https://github.com/OHIF/Viewers.git


yarn install to restore dependencies and link projects

To Develop
From this repository's root directory:
# Enable Yarn Workspaces
yarn config set workspaces-experimental true

# Restore dependencies
yarn install
Commands
These commands are available from the root directory. Each project directory
also supports a number of commands that can be found in their respective
README.md and package.json files.



Yarn Commands
Description

dev or start

Jest multi-project test runner; overall coverage

build*
Builds production output for our PWA Viewer

This file format contains important information about the image, such as the type of image, the patient's name, and other relevant data. We can categorize the medical image viewers into two groups: Desktop and Web. The Desktop viewers include programs that are installed on the computer. On the other hand, Web viewers are accessed through a web browser and allow remote viewing of data without the need to download an application. Important Considerations When Selecting a DICOM ViewerThere are a few essential considerations to keep in mind when selecting a web-based DICOM viewer. First, the viewer should be able to handle the various types of DICOM images (CT, MRI, etc.). In addition, it is helpful if the viewer offers a variety of features and options for viewing, manipulating images, and annotations, as this can be very useful for medical professionals. Finally, it is crucial to ensure that the viewer is compatible with medical professionals’ existing workflows. Existing Web-Based DICOM Viewers AvailableThe Open Health Imaging Foundation's (OHIF) viewer platform (hereafter OHIF Viewer) is a zero-footprint open-source medical imaging platform which provides the ability to view and interact with medical images in a web browser and create workflows and export reports. Other notable open-source medical imaging platforms include DICOM Web Viewer (DWV) and Med3Web Viewer.All three viewers are written in JavaScript and provide an interface for visualization and interaction with medical images. As per community engagements and developer contributions, OHIF has more than 1,900 stars on GitHub and more than 200 contributors, DWV has 1,300 stars and 27 contributors, and Med3Web Viewer has 214 stars and 12 contributors. The MedDream viewer is a closed-source viewer that provides a standard interface for viewing and interacting with medical images in a web browser; however, its source code is not open, and the license is not free. OHIF vs Other Mainstream Web-Based DICOM ViewersA major challenge for image viewers is the compatibility with existing workflows. OHIF can communicate with custom servers and PACS systems and is compatible with the DICOMweb standards for communicating with DICOM data; however, the DWV and Med3Web Viewers are not compatible with DICOMweb. Another area that OHIF excels in is viewing and loading various types of DICOM data, such as DICOM-RT, DICOM SR, and DICOM-SEG. OHIF also provides standard authentication and authorization workflow for the viewer, which is unavailable in the DWV and Med3Web Viewer. OHIF has been professionally designed and developed to be an easy-to-use, extensible, and robust viewer with a User Interface that is intuitive for radiologists and medical professionals. The Importance of Using Open Source SoftwareThere are many benefits to open source software, including the fact that it is usually free to use and distribute and that it often comes with a large community of users and developers who can offer support and help improve the software. Open-source software enables greater customization and extensibility, which can be very useful for complex medical imaging applications that often require highly specific and customized workflows.  OHIF is Our Go-To DICOM ViewerA Web-based DICOM viewer can be an invaluable tool for radiologists and other medical professionals if it is feature-rich, professionally designed, and compatible with various data types and existing workflows. OHIF is an open-source DICOM viewer that is designed to meet these requirements. That’s why it’s our go-to when building custom viewers and workflows for our clients at Radical Imaging. Get in touch with us if you’ve been dreaming up a perfect medical imaging viewer for your own unique use case. We’d love to hear about it and help you build it!References: OHIFDWVMed3WebMedDream"},{"title":"How to Choose a Web-Based DICOM Viewer | Radical Imaging","link":"https://devopedia.org/ohif-viewer","content":"
        
        A screenshot of OHIF Viewer. Source: OHIF 2023a. Doctors and other medical professionals use software to view, analyse and annotate images of patients. These images could be X-rays, ultrasound/CT/PET/MRI scans, ECG/EEG waves and more. There are both commercial as well as open source viewers for this purpose. Among the open source viewers is OHIF Viewer. It's development is guided by the Open Health Imaging Foundation (OHIF). 
The OHIF Viewer is configurable and extensible. It's a web application that can be used without additional software installation. It can load images from various sources or interfaces including DICOMweb. Images can be rendered in 2D, 3D or restructured representations. For authentication it supports OpenID Connect. The app is built in React using reusable UI components.  
      
    
        
      Discussion
      
                
          Could you give an overview of OHIF Viewer?
          A typical radiology workflow. Source: Dikici et al. 2019, fig. 2. Let's consider a radiology workflow as an example. Via CT or MRI scans of patients, images are acquired. These images are in DICOM (Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine) format. They're sent to a DICOM router that checks the integrity of these images. From here the images are sent to Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS) and Vendor-Neutral Archive (VNA). An example of PACS is Orthanc, a DICOM server with REST API and a web UI.  
Radiologists access the images in PACS from their workstations or other devices for visualization, post-processing or analysis. Non-radiologists can access images from VNA via patient Electronic Medical Record (EMR). The figure above shows a case where this traditional workflow is being augmented with AI capabilities. 
Traditional medical imaging software were often desktop applications that needed to be installed and maintained by IT staff. When problems arose, such applications were hard to debug remotely. It's in this context that web-based applications enabled by cloud computing became attractive. The OHIF Viewer is one such viewer. 
        
                
          What are the main features of OHIF Viewer?
          The viewer includes two essential features: visualization and annotation. For visualization, multi-modal image fusion, maximum intensity projection, multi-planar reformatting, axial/sagittal/coronal views, CINE view, and many more are supported. For annotation, there are many easy-to-use tools for measurement and annotation. Touch-specific tools such as pinch-to-zoom become handy on touchscreen devices.  
In terms of software architecture and design, the viewer is built using reusable React UI components. This enables developers to compose more sophisticated components and custom workflows without needing to code them from scratch. Since code is open source, these components can be studied and customized as needed. The viewer is really a web application that runs within a web browser. Hence, no additional software needs to be installed to use it. 
For performance, GPU acceleration is used for image rendering. Multi-threading enables quick image decoding. 
The viewer is standards-compliant: DICOMweb for image data access, OpenID Connect for authorized access to data. The viewer can connect other sources as well. 
For deployment, the viewer can be a standalone web application. Alternatively, it can be embedded via a <script> tag into another application but this got deprecated in version 3. 
        
                
          What's the architecture of OHIF Viewer?
          Architecture of OHIF Viewer. Source: OHIF 2022d, slide 7. The OHIF Viewer adopts a modular architecture. The main platform has the following components: 

core: Core libraries that implement medical imaging functions (aka business logic) for the web.
i18n: Internationalization support.
viewer: This brings together the all components. To register extensions, compose modes and route requests are its main functions.
ui: React component library.
extensions: Libraries that implement essential functionalities such as rendering, measurement tracking, etc. These are the building blocks. They're consumed by modes.
modes: A configuration to compose extensions and routes to make an application.OHIF Viewer makes use of other projects such as Cornerstone. It's a set of JavaScript libraries specific to the medical domain. Cornerstone also include libraries to load DICOM objects over the web, called WADO (Web Access to DICOM Objects). There's support for the older WADO-URI interface and the more modern WADO-RS aka DICOMweb (RESTful API). The loader uses web workers for CPU intensive image processing tasks.  It uses OpenJPEG library. Library dcmjs does DICOM manipulation in JavaScript. 
        
                
          What are modes in OHIF Viewer?
          The composition of a mode or a mini app. Source: OHIF 2022e. The OHIF Viewer contains many extensions but often not all of them are needed for a specific workflow. For example, 3D segmentation has different requirements compared to tracking measurements over time. Other specific workflows are ECG viewer and total metabolic tumor volume. These different workflows are enabled via modes. In one sense, modes enable many mini-apps or workflows within a single app. 
Modes use extensions. Modes register workflows with the viewer with certain routes. The mode will get invoked once user accesses the viewer on a registered route. Modes essentially offer a lot of flexibility to create new workflows while reusing existing extensions. Modes were introduced in version 3. In version 2 of the viewer, we had to build new UI and extensions to create new workflows. 
The figure shows the composition of "AI Organ Segmentation" mode. It configures the applicable routes and extensions. It uses the applicable layout templates and data sources. Mode-specific props are passed to the templates. For each study, the viewer will show available modes. A study can have multiple modes.  
        
                
          Could you do a code walkthrough of OHIF Viewer?
          We describe the codebase with respect to commit beb451745 (December 2022). Paths to the components are configured in tsconfig.json. For example, the viewer component is at platform/viewer/src. At this path we find index.js where the application object is created. This object is inserted into the DOM at the element with ID "root". The HTML template for this is at platform/viewer/public/html_templates/index.html. 
For interfacing to a DICOMweb server, the configuration files are at platform/viewer/public/config folder. Data is requested via the extension extensions/cornerstone/src/utils/dicomLoaderServer.js. Web workers are initialized in extensions/cornerstone/src/initWADOImageLoader.js. 
The default mode is configured in modes/basic-dev-mode/src/index.js. Modes are set up for the app in platform/viewer/src/appInit.js. 
Reusable React components are in platform/ui/src/components. As an example, we note that ToolbarButton is built from three other components, Tooltip, IconButton and Icon. Some extensions make use of ToolbarButton to compose a complete toolbar. 
        
                
          What developer resources are available to work with OHIF Viewer?
          The project's main website has links to documentation, examples, and more. Beginners may want to explore a demo of the software first.
The source code is available on GitHub. We can clone this code repository and build a Docker image of the viewer. Alternatively, we can use the viewer's Docker image from Docker Hub.
An easier way to use OHIF Viewer is as a cloud-based managed service. SpringML's One-Click DICOM Viewer is an example that's easily deployed on the Google Cloud. It uses Google Kubernetes Engine. 
Perhaps the easiest method is to embed the viewer via a script tag into your own custom application. 
OHIF Viewer is capable of invoking DICOMweb REST APIs. A cheatsheet of DICOMweb is a useful reference. 
OHIF Viewer uses Cornerstone. It's a set of JavaScript libraries to display medical images, or develop tools and applications for medical imaging.  
        
              
    
    
        
      Milestones
      
                OHIF Viewer v1 demo showing the use of web workers. Source: OHIF 2016, slide 20. Dr. Gordon Harris at the Massachusetts General Hospital receives funding for the project from a National Cancer Institute U24 grant. This funding continues till August 2020. Version 1 of the software starts life in 2015 and is active till 2019. It's uses Meteor full-stack framework. Version 1 is actually three separate apps: LesionTracker, OHIF Viewer, and OHIF Standalone Viewer. 
                
          
          XNAT integrates OHIF Viewer within its environment. XNAT is a platform for quantitative imaging studies. This evolves as new versions of the viewer are released in later years: XNAT-OHIF 2.0 (2019) and XNAT-OHIF 3.2.0 (2021).  This is just one example of other projects adopting OHIF Viewer. 
        
                
          
          OHIF Viewer v2 is released. It's a single React app. It deprecates the Meteor backend. Version 2 remains in active development till 2021. The viewer's extension architecture is one of the features in this version. Others include 3D multiplanar reformatting (MPR), DICOM segmentation, and PDF visualization. 
        
                
          
          Release v0.0.19 of OHIF Viewer occurs via it's code repository on GitHub. This is the first release via GitHub. Semantic versioning of the project starts here. In May, v0.1.0 is released. From August, each package is released separately since this is a monorepo. For example, @ohif/core@0.11.1-alpha.8 and @ohif/extension-cornerstone@0.0.39-alpha.8 are released in August, each with its own release numbering. 
        
                
          
          The Chan Zuckerberg Initiative selects both OHIF and Cornerstone projects for funding. The funds would go towards better documentation, software maintenance and community outreach. Funding begins in 2021. In August 2021, the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative partners with hack.diversity to develop new training material, and provide guidance and mentorship to contributors working on these projects. This funding is renewed in 2022. 
        
                
          
          OHIF Viewer v3 Public Beta is released. This is a departure from the Meteor-based v1 and current React-based version v2. The app is still in React but has a new UI component library that uses Tailwind CSS. Via a major re-architecture, modes are introduced. Extensions in v2 were hard to maintain. Modes assemble extensions via a more modular approach. 
        
                
          
          At a OHIF Viewer demo and presentation, it's reported that the software will evolve to support advanced features. These include hanging protocols, volume rendering, rendering of arbitrary stack of images, rendering of colour images, videos, ECG viewer, pathology viewer, etc. 
        
                
          
          OHIF Viewer v3.3 is released. Among the new features are DICOM segmentation, multiplanar reformatting (MPR), synchronized scrolling, and reference lines. DICOM segments, rendered in 3D, are for display only and can't be edited. MPR feature uses Cornerstone3D VolumeViewports feature. Project will continue to look at bug fixes on v2-stable branch but will focus on v3-stable branch for the long term.  This release also deprecates the Embedded Viewer.

The OHIF (Open Health Imaging Foundation) Viewer is a popular open-source DICOM viewer. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to use the OHIF Viewer to view your DICOM images:

1. **Installation**:
   - If you haven't already, you'll need to install the OHIF Viewer. You can either use it online or host it on your own server. For self-hosting, you can follow the installation instructions provided on the OHIF Viewer's GitHub repository.

2. **Access the Viewer**:
   - If you're using the online version, simply navigate to the OHIF Viewer's website.
   - If you've self-hosted, access the viewer by navigating to the appropriate URL on your server.

3. **Load DICOM Images**:
   - Once you're in the viewer, you'll typically see an option to load local DICOM files or connect to a PACS (Picture Archiving and Communication System).
   - To load local DICOM files, click on the option to load files and navigate to the location of your DICOM images on your computer. Select the images and they should load into the viewer.
   - If you're connecting to a PACS, you'll need to provide the necessary connection details (like the PACS server address, port, etc.). Once connected, you can search for and load DICOM studies from the PACS.

4. **Navigate and Analyze Images**:
   - Once the images are loaded, you can navigate through them using the provided tools.
   - The viewer offers various tools for analyzing the images, such as zoom, pan, window/level, and measurement tools. Familiarize yourself with these tools to make the most of the viewer.

5. **Annotations and Measurements**:
   - OHIF Viewer allows you to add annotations and measurements to the images. These can be saved and loaded later if needed.

6. **Extensions and Plugins**:
   - OHIF Viewer supports various extensions and plugins that can enhance its functionality. Depending on your needs, you might want to explore and install these extensions.

7. **Save and Export**:
   - After analyzing and annotating the images, you can save your work. Some versions of the viewer might also offer options to export the images or the annotations.

8. **Troubleshooting**:
   - If you face any issues, refer to the documentation or the community forums for the OHIF Viewer. They can provide solutions to common problems and guidance on how to use the viewer effectively.

For more detailed instructions and troubleshooting, you might want to refer to the [official OHIF documentation](https://docs.ohif.org/) or the [OHIF Viewer's GitHub repository](https://github.com/OHIF/Viewers).

Remember, the exact steps and features might vary slightly based on the version of the OHIF Viewer you're using and any customizations that have been applied. Always refer to the documentation relevant to your specific version for the most accurate information.

  OHIF Medical Imaging Viewer
  The OHIF Viewer is a zero-footprint medical image viewer
provided by the Open Health Imaging Foundation (OHIF). It is a configurable and extensible progressive web application with out-of-the-box support for image archives which support DICOMweb.



























Measurement Tracking
Demo



Labelmap Segmentations
Demo



Fusion and Custom Hanging protocols
Demo



Slide Microscopy
Demo



Volume Rendering

About
The OHIF Medical Imaging Viewer is for viewing medical images. It can retrieve
and load images from most sources and formats; render sets in 2D, 3D, and
reconstructed representations; allows for the manipulation, annotation, and
serialization of observations; supports internationalization, OpenID Connect,
offline use, hotkeys, and many more features.
Almost everything offers some degree of customization and configuration. If it
doesn't support something you need, we accept pull requests and have an ever
improving Extension System.
Why Choose Us
Community & Experience
The OHIF Viewer is a collaborative effort that has served as the basis for many
active, production, and FDA Cleared medical imaging viewers. It benefits from
our extensive community's collective experience, and from the sponsored
contributions of individuals, research groups, and commercial organizations.
Built to Adapt
After more than 8-years of integrating with many companies and organizations,
The OHIF Viewer has been rebuilt from the ground up to better address the
varying workflow and configuration needs of its many users. All of the Viewer's
core features are built using it's own extension system. The same extensibility
that allows us to offer:

2D and 3D medical image viewing
Multiplanar Reconstruction (MPR)
Maximum Intensity Project (MIP)
Whole slide microscopy viewing
PDF and Dicom Structured Report rendering
Segmentation rendering as labelmaps and contours
User Access Control (UAC)
Context specific toolbar and side panel content
and many others

Can be leveraged by you to customize the viewer for your workflow, and to add
any new functionality you may need (and wish to maintain privately without
forking).
Support

Report a Bug 🐛
Request a Feature 🚀
Ask a Question 🤗
Slack Channel

For commercial support, academic collaborations, and answers to common
questions; please use Get Support to contact
us.
Developing
Branches
master branch - The latest dev (beta) release

master - The latest dev release

This is typically where the latest development happens. Code that is in the master branch has passed code reviews and automated tests, but it may not be deemed ready for production. This branch usually contains the most recent changes and features being worked on by the development team. It's often the starting point for creating feature branches (where new features are developed) and hotfix branches (for urgent fixes).
Each package is tagged with beta version numbers, and published to npm such as @ohif/ui@3.6.0-beta.1
release branch - The latest stable release
This branch represents the latest stable version of the project that is considered ready for production. The code in this branch should be fully tested and vetted for release. Once the code in the master branch reaches a state where it's stable and ready to be released to users,
we do a comprehensive code review and QA testing. Once the code is approved,
we merge it into the release branch and tag a new release.
Each package is tagged with version numbers, and published to npm such as @ohif/ui@3.5.0
Note: master is always ahead of release branch. We publish both docker builds for beta and stable releases.

To Develop

# Restore dependencies

  @ohif/viewer
  @ohif/viewer is a zero-footprint medical image viewer provided by the Open Health Imaging Foundation (OHIF). It is a configurable and extensible progressive web application with out-of-the-box support for image archives which support DICOMweb.












ATTENTION: If you are looking for Version 1 (the Meteor Version) of this
repository, it lives on
the v1.x branch

Why?
Building a web based medical imaging viewer from scratch is time intensive, hard
to get right, and expensive. Instead of re-inventing the wheel, you can use the
OHIF Viewer as a rock solid platform to build on top of. The Viewer is a
React Progressive Web Application that can be embedded
in existing applications via it's packaged source
(ohif-viewer) or hosted stand-alone. The Viewer exposes
configuration and extensions to support
workflow customization and advanced functionality at common integration points.
If you're interested in using the OHIF Viewer, but you're not sure it supports
your use case check out our docs. Still not sure, or
you would like to propose new features? Don't hesitate to
create an issue or open a pull
request.
Getting Started
This readme is specific to testing and developing locally. If you're more
interested in production deployment strategies,
you can check out our documentation on publishing.
Want to play around before you dig in?
Check out our LIVE Demo
Setup
Requirements:

NodeJS & NPM
Yarn

Steps:

Fork this repository
Clone your forked repository (your origin)


git clone git@github.com:YOUR_GITHUB_USERNAME/Viewers.git


Add OHIF/Viewers as a remote repository (the upstream)


git remote add upstream git@github.com:OHIF/Viewers.git

Developing Locally
In your cloned repository's root folder, run:
// Restore dependencies
yarn install

// Stands up local server to host Viewer.
// Viewer connects to our public cloud PACS by default
yarn start
For more advanced local development scenarios, like using your own locally
hosted PACS and test data,
check out our Essential: Getting Started
guide.
E2E Tests
Using Cypress to create End-to-End tests and check
whether the application flow is performing correctly, ensuring that the
integrated components are working as expected.
Why Cypress?
Cypress is a next generation front end testing tool built for the modern web.
With Cypress is easy to set up, write, run and debug tests
It allow us to write different types of tests:

End-to-End tests
Integration tests
Unit tets

All tests must be in ./cypress/integration folder.
Commands to run the tests:
// Open Cypress Dashboard that provides insight into what happened when your tests ran
yarn test:e2e

// Run all tests using Electron browser headless
yarn test:e2e:local

// Run all tests in CI mode
yarn run test:e2e:ci
Contributing

Large portions of the Viewer's functionality are maintained in other
repositories. To get a better understanding of the Viewer's architecture and
"where things live", read
our docs on the Viewer's architecture

It is notoriously difficult to setup multiple dependent repositories for
end-to-end testing and development. That's why we recommend writing and running
unit tests when adding and modifying features. This allows us to program in
isolation without a complex setup, and has the added benefit of producing
well-tested business logic.

Clone this repository
Navigate to the project directory, and yarn install

To begin making changes, yarn run dev

To commit changes, run yarn run cm


When creating tests, place the test file "next to" the file you're testing.
For example:
// File
index.js;

// Test for file
index.test.js;
As you add and modify code, jest will watch for uncommitted changes and run
your tests, reporting the results to your terminal. Make a pull request with
your changes to master, and a core team member will review your work. If you
have any questions, please don't hesitate to reach out via a GitHub issue.
